title: A rare brawl breaks out in race for Onondaga County executive
text:
Early voting began Oct. 26, and Election Day is Nov. 5. | Getty Images A rare brawl breaks out in race for Onondaga County executive

SYRACUSE — For the first time in recent memory, a Democrat appears to have a fighting chance to manage Onondaga County's government.

Tony Malavenda, who spent the last 40 years in the sewer business, has thrown $800,000 of his own cash into a campaign to unseat incumbent County Executive Ryan McMahon. Malavenda's message is that unchallenged control of Onondaga's government has prevented the county and its urban center, Syracuse, from thriving.

Story Continued Below

While Onondaga County has 109,733 registered Democrats to 82,675 Republicans, and includes the traditionally blue academics and youths connected to Syracuse University, it has long been an upstate Republican stronghold. With the GOP seeking to recover from the blows it suffered in last year's state Senate elections, the contest in Central New York could be an early test for new state chair Nick Langworthy and his allies.

Malavenda, a Syracuse native, said his bid for elected office is an outgrowth of his years of dissatisfaction with what he called “pay-to-play, gerrymandering and crony-ism” in the county. Nothing he has seen since becoming a candidate has caused him to reconsider.

“I thought I was cynical before, but then I started running and I realized I just can’t keep up,” he told POLITICO. “I came out of the sewer business and I feel like I went down a level.”

The county's GOP establishment seems to be less than flustered by a determined challenger with an atypical amount of resources.

“I’ve got street credit,” McMahon said during an interview in his 14th floor office in Syracuse, lit by broad windows looking out on the city's downtown and the rolling Central New York hills where his rural constituents live.

The county's Democrats helped boost the House candidacy of Dana Balter, who ultimately lost to GOP incumbent Rep. John Katko in a competitive race in 2018. The county has been represented in the state Senate for years by both a Republican and Democrat — currently Sens. Bob Antonacci and Rachel May, respectively.

But at the very local level, Republicans have firmly held the reins of county government for decades thanks to strong leadership, its influence in the county’s towns and villages, and a relatively large enrollment in the Independence and Conservative parties. The last Democrat elected to countywide office was former district attorney Bob Wildridge in the 1980s. A Democrat has never been elected comptroller or executive.

McMahon, 39, is a product of the GOP organization. He has spent more than 14 years in elected office and was quickly appointed from chair of the county legislature to temporarily replace executive Joanie Mahoney when she stepped down last year. Mahoney was successful in pushing economic development in the region through close ties with Gov. Andrew Cuomo, but was also known for tense relationships with former Syracuse mayor Stephanie Miner, a Democrat, as well as Republican county leaders.

McMahon said he has strong alliances on both sides of the aisle from his time as city councilor and legislator, and has touted his record in fighting poverty in the county. Although Syracuse remains one of the nation’s poorest cities with a 30.5 percent poverty rate, that figure dropped by 2 percent last year to the lowest in a decade. Unemployment in the city — at 3.9 percent — is trending down, he says, because the city is adding more jobs.

The county’s books are balanced (it ran a surplus last year), its credit ratings are high, and McMahon said he and Syracuse Mayor Ben Walsh, an independent, are bringing together academia, elected officials and the business community to benefit the city.

“Because we’re getting along and sending those signals to everyone else, the private sector is willing to invest,” he said.

That’s what’s important to voters, not his party affiliation, he says.

“Our folks aren’t these partisan residents. If they were, I wouldn’t be here,” he said.

Malavenda doesn’t entirely disagree. His outrage isn’t so much based on party as it is on what he sees as a complacent status quo that works against Syracuse’s revitalization. He said he has seen other distressed cities — Pittsburgh, Minneapolis, even Buffalo — rebuild their populations and reputations. But Syracuse has never been able to mount a steady recovery from the exodus of manufacturing jobs that began in the 1970s.

“Survival of the fittest means survival of the species that can best adapt to change,” he said. “Because this government is so locked in — doing the things the way they’ve always done it, and keeping everybody there and in power — we have not adapted here. And that is, I think, the biggest question.”

Malavenda, 63, isn’t a typical system disrupter. His only campaign experience was a failed run for county legislature as 27-year-old in 1983. He graduated from Georgetown University’s School of Foreign Service and briefly studied international relations at the London School of Economics. He moved back to Syracuse before completing his masters, after he was recruited by a childhood friend to work on sewer systems. He did that for four decades.

He and his friend sold their company, Duke’s Root Control, last December. Malavenda won’t say how much he sold the company for, but it’s enough that he had no trouble doubling his initial contribution of $400,000 to his campaign when he realized he needed more resources to keep up with McMahon.

The job of county executive essentially entails running a business, he said, and working in infrastructure gave him experience in coordinating a range of services. Malavenda has poured funding into attack ads on McMahon’s rise to power and the money and party connections that cleared the way for him.

As of earlier this month, McMahon ‘s campaign has raised more than $700,000 from individuals, firms, unions and others. Malavenda, who has raised a little over $60,000, said that without his own money there’s no way he or anyone else could keep up — “not in this town.”

He has leveled serious accusations against McMahon, claiming that he was involved in a ponzi scheme, which McMahon has vigorously denied. The charge was made in a television ad, leading a lawyer for McMahon to demand that local television stations stop running the ad or risk a libel suit.

The aggressive campaign could backfire on Malavenda, said Grant Reeher, the director of the Campbell Public Affairs Institute and a professor of political science at Syracuse University.

Some of the ads have misconstrued McMahon’s influence and ties with those of his predecessor, according to The Post-Standard. And they include little specific policy to persuade voters that what they have isn’t working. Criticisms of pay raises and the compensation paid to county officials have been raised in previous elections and haven't gained much traction, he said.

“He [McMahon] is keen on making his own mark and I think he’s in a very good position to do so,” Reeher said. “I don’t think there’s a big reason to send him packing.”

Still, the opposition from Malavenda is enough that McMahon has launched response ads, signaling that some of the accusations may have hit a mark with voters. And Langworthy, the state GOP chair, held an event at the county’s Republican headquarters on Oct. 23 to defend McMahon.

“You have a county executive that is standing for reelection and running on his record,” Langworthy said.“You have one candidate who decided he was going to take this race to the toilet."

“I think the only thing people know about him is that he doesn’t like me,” McMahon said.

While neither candidate is shying from a fight, there is one divisive topic they’re happy to leave out of the campaign discussion.

"What do you think about Trump?" asked a woman at a meet and greet with about a dozen residents at Valley Vista Apartments in Syracuse.

“Nope,” the facility’s event coordinator said. "We’re not doing that. They are running for the county, not the country.”

The two candidates bumped fists.

“He [Malavenda] looked at me and smirked,” McMahon said later. “That was probably the nicest moment we’ve had.”

Democrats are also challenging GOP incumbents for district attorney, comptroller and county clerk. Early voting began Oct. 26, and Election Day is Nov. 5.
description: A political outsider hopes to become the county's first Democratic leader.
